name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text: JRC: "Stimulus and relief bills are different. The earlier CARES legislation was to provide relief and hopefully by the end of the year we'll turn the corner and be able to talk about stimulus bills."

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
HERD IMMUNITY: Around 70% of Utahns would have to be immune to #COVID19. However, we know that reinfection is possible and don't know how long immunity lasts.

E.g. You could get a common cold several times a year-- no immunity exists. That could be the case w/the coronavirus.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text: .@DrAngelaCDunn on the vaccine: "The FDA will not release the vaccine until it's approved and gone through all the proper channels. There's a firewall between those working on the vaccine and politicians-- it will be safe when it has the approval from the @US_FDA."

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Are hospitals overwhelmed?
"Referring to actual beds, we have them. The limiting factor is healthcare providers, esp. high-level ICU care w/only so many providers to go around...We all need to really think about what more we can do as individuals to limit transmission." -Dr. Dunn

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text: "We need to change mindsets about what's reasonable activity during a pandemic, esp. when hospitals are overwhelmed. To get our case counts down, we need to only socialize w/people in our households, wear face coverings when we're out & stay home when we're sick." -@DrAngelaCDunn

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text: It was a mental hurdle to start wearing a mask to the grocery store and out in public. The mental hurdle we all need to cross is wearing a mask around our loved ones too-- that's where most of the new cases are coming from.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
What do you want businesses to know?

"Most new cases are not from people engaging in commerce or people going to work. It's people not practicing those same safe behaviors outside of work that they are when they are at work." -@DerekMillerUtah

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Does wearing a mask and keeping six feet make a difference?

"Masks and staying away from people are the best ways to stop transmissions, especially as we hear about cases being transmitted by those with no symptoms." - @DrAngelaCDunn

name: Rep. John Curtis

On media bias:

I don't think we can dictate our opinions based on something we hear on cable networks. Additionally, it's a real shame that so much of our public opinion is based on a tweet or facebook post. It's upon ourselves to dig deeper and seek out unbiased information.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text: I compliment @GovHerbert's handling of #COVID19-- it's been hard to navigate. We've never seen this before and it has changed midstream. I think he's done a fabulous job at striking a balance and I applaud him turning some of the decisions over to local leaders such as mayors.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
‚ùìThoughts on term limits for the House and Senate:

I'm a big fan of term limits. I've tried to limit myself in political office. I was having one of the best experiences of my life as Provo mayor but felt after eight years it was time for someone else to take over.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
‚ùì: Is there a specific plan you support to reopen the schools?

A: I believe the decisions should stay local with mayors and school boards where the local community can have a say.

name: Rep. John Curtis

‚ùì: Restart of nuclear tests in Utah

A: Clearly we've had bad experiences with nuclear testing here in the state. Perhaps there are places in the country where it's appropriate to test, but I'm not aware of anyone who would support that here in Utah.

tweet_text: Thank you for all who were able to join us tonight. We'll eventually get back to the public ones and continue to experiment with different virtual formats. If you had a question we didn't get to, please call my office: üìû(801) 922-5400 #utpol

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
‚ùìIf #COVID19 mostly affects those 80+, why are we all pausing normal life?

I wear my mask bc I don't know when/if I'm a carrier of the disease. We've learned how to open restaurants & businesses w/safety precautions but won't be able to evaluate fully until it's all truly over.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Bailing out other cities and states?

Provo, and Utah generally, planned ahead and will weather this pandemic far better than other cities and states. We shouldn't be penalized for other poor management elsewhere. 

My op-ed about this: https://t.co/vDl2elmZdv

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
‚ùìFederal deficit?

Very frustrating to see members of both parties not caring about this. I've introduced a bill requiring all future emergency or disaster spending be offset over a ten year period. More:
https://t.co/MpckOQALct

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Why "no" on the USPS bill?

1. Gave the USPS $25 billion (they already have enough cash [$24B] on hand to operate well into next year)
2. Mandated no more changes + undid any previous 2020 changes

If the concern is election security, the bill didn't help with that.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Thoughts on nuclear energy?

- It's one of our shortcuts to removing carbon in the air. I am hopeful that US innovation and tech will move nuclear to a whole different level of safety and efficiency but has to be a part of our package moving forward. ‚ö°Ô∏è

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Clearer #covid19 guidelines on a federal level? 

-Some things (like masks) are universal, but guidelines that apply to NYC might not apply to San Juan County. Individuals have had to step up and be wise, careful stewards over their health, their homes, their neighborhoods.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
‚ùì's about mail-in voting:
I have huge confidence that every signature will be checked, verified, amazingly accurate and timely here in Utah. I'm not as confident across the US. 

I spoke on the House floor about this last week: 
https://t.co/zFrYNQCN3I

name: Rep. John Curtis

Are there Utah hotspots? 

Yes, there's a hotspot in North Orem right now. When this happens, the state develops a "strike team" in the sense of going in and figuring out what's happening in a particular neighborhood, do some mobile testing, etc.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
What should businesses do if they haven't received aid?

Learn about every opportunity to get some immediate financing: the EIDL (you can get a grant of $10K upfront) Paycheck Protection Program, the CARES Act (defer payroll/employer side roll taxes, or carry back taxes)

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:

Check out my rural broadband bill below ‚§µÔ∏è

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: What will the third wave of legislation include? 

A: We hope to include things that won't add to the national debt, such as banking regulations, that can provide resources for businesses but won't add to the deficit.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: Do masks really work and why do they matter?

A: Masks cut down the transmission of the disease. We'd like to create a culture in Utah where wearing a mask is a responsible, civic token of helping your neighbors and helping yourself.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: What's the benefit of quarantining the community vs just those in high risk? 

A: If everyone were exposed, many more get sick and we'd eclipse our healthcare capacity. This gave us more space to get ahold of PPE (masks and gowns).

Q: Are there enough tests in Utah?

A: Right now, Utah has the capacity to test anyone with symptoms consistent with COVID19. You can and should be tested.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: Why are medical masks so hard to come by?

A: The supply doesn't meet the demand. We were not prepared from a supply chain standpoint & now the entire world needs them. 

üö®The @CDCgov & @GovHerbert recommend cloth masks for the public; N95 masks are for medical professionals.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: Will the warmer weather bring #COVID19 relief?

A: No data to support either way. Influenza is seasonal in some areas but constant in tropical regions. Just because it's warming up doesn't mean we'll see relief. This is a novel virus-- we don't know how it'll be affected.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: When will we get back to normal life? 

A: First we need to get over the peak, and then wait at least two incubation periods (about a month total) and then start slowly going back into normal life. It won't be a light switch flipped back on.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: Could those who test negative go back to work to help the economy?

A: No because testing negative means you don't have the virus that day, not that you're immune. There's no choice between the economy or lives: if we let people die, the economy is destroyed for a lot longer.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: How is this different from SARS?

A: SARS was lethal but didn‚Äôt spread with the same efficacy. COVID19 is spread more easily, by coughing, sneezing and droplets, plus 80% with this virus are walking around with a mild illness able to spread it unknowingly.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: Could parts of the country start moving again? Will normal life return all at once? 

A: Depends on us. Each city/state has the power to control the scope with social distancing. We're pretty well ahead of the curve in Utah for preventing/slowing the spread- let's stick w/it!

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Q: Why do we social distance? Why not carry about our normal lives?

A: If we let the disease move unchecked, we'll have far too many cases than hospitals can handle.

By keeping the wave down, we have time to develop drugs to treat this and eventually an effective vaccine.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
A caller asks if we could have been more prepared had we known earlier about the coronavirus. 

Just this week I introduced a bill that would encourage global public officials to be transparent about public health crises for that very reason. 

More:
https://t.co/lTdqFk8RD5

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
Thanks for all those from Rural Utah who joined in.

Now starting the second half of our town hall, focused on Utah County and Salt Lake County.

TUNE IN HERE: https://t.co/a76Ffco2Js

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
In Utah we're performing 2600 tests a day, last week was 100. We'll continue increasing the amount of testing and if you think you need to be tested, talk to your doctor and it can be called into order. 

BUT the vast majority being tested are testing negative. üëçüèº

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text:
On adequate testing in rural Utah: 

Unless you are having difficulties breathing, there's no point in getting a test because there is no medicine to cure it yet. Stay home and take care of yourself. If you develop complications, the hospital will be ready to take care of you.

name: Rep. John Curtis
tweet_text: More details on the one-time tax rebate check: $1,200 per individual, $2,400 per couple and $500 per eligible child.

name: Rep. John Curtis

See what telehealth options are available. Most places have a digital option easily accessible for those with symptoms and would like a consultation but aren't in an urgent state.

name: Rep. John Curtis

A constituent asks about the deficit and comments on how big the price tag on the new stimulus package. 

Rep. Curtis also feels it‚Äôs extremely expensive, but crucial bill and will be addressing some of those concerns in a speech on the House floor tomorrow morning.

name: Rep. John Curtis

A. We‚Äôll have a better idea as time goes on‚Äî but this is why we‚Äôre practicing social distancing to stay ahead of the 4-6 week curve we‚Äôre seeing in other countries.
